title: Greed and the Pharmaceutical Industry-Ron Piana.mp4

segments.text: I say that not to brag about my credentials, but just to let the audience know who I am.
Because what I'm about to talk about later on in the story challenges a $200 billion per year cancer industry.
And anytime you challenge that type of power structure, there's blowback.
They will try to discredit me, but they can't because I'm an insider.
I'm one of them.
My road to science writing was unconventional.
I didn't go the usual high school, college, career path.
I grew up in Syosset, a town on the north shore of Long Island, New York.
It's called a commuter town because it runs along the spine of the Long Island Railroad.
I came from a very dysfunctional and poor family.
My mother was bipolar.
She was an original conspiracy theorist.
She claimed to be abducted by a ufo.
And when John Kennedy was assassinated, that was sort of her tipping point.
Any maternal instinct, the little she had vanished.
And so I was basically on my own at an early age.
My father waited tables at a German American restaurant called Rothman's.
And when I was 14, I started working there.
And I was making about 40, 50 bucks a week.
So that's 1967.
I was doing very well.
I was on my own.
And by 15, I'd established myself as a man.
I was self sufficient.
And two things were very prominent in my life, hard work and hard drinking.
I could do both of those and that would define much of who I later on became.
So I always had a keen eye for adventure.
And at 15 years old, I with a buddy of mine, this guy named Terry McQuaid, we hitchhiked down to Florida to visit my uncle and Asa, who was an orange picker.
He lived out in the outback of Florida in a tin roofed house set up on cinder blocks with 12 kids, my cousins.
There was no indoor plumbing.
I was poor, but this was southern dirt poor.
It was a really wild experience.
They were so far removed.
And this is 1968, they were so far removed that my cousins had never heard of the Beatles.
Okay, so we picked oranges for a few weeks and then we took a train back after that.
I didn't go to college.
There was never any talk of college in our household.
We didn't have any money and just wasn't part of the discussion.
So I had an opportunity.
I went to Paris and I lived in a flat on Rhuda Mosque, right by Gare Saint Lazare.
And I worked at a place called Hettyard as a prep cook.
Hetty Yard was a very Very high end emporium, food emporium.
And I did that for about a year and a year and a half, and then I came back and bounced around as an itinerant cook.
I ended up back in Rothmans, where I originally started.
And as it happened, there were some Norwegian shipping brokers that used to drink there.
And I buddied up with this guy named Captain Melansto.
He was a hard drinker, as I was.
And we started talking and I wanted to follow my childhood literary heroes and go to sea.
But at that time, our merchant marine, our merchant merchant marines was the size of a dime and they were all unionized.
It was impossible to get on.
So I begged him, I said, literally begged him, I said, can you get me on a ship?
And he said, well, we're shipping brokers, but we do own one ship.
She's called the Sovereign Edith, and she's.
Right now she's dry docked in New Orleans.
He said.
But he was very frank.
He said, I would not in good conscience send you aboard the Edith because she flies the Liberian flag and it's a very dangerous environment, especially for an American, a white American.
But I prevailed on him and finally said, okay.
So I joined the Sovereign Edith and it was a wild experience.
Experience.
